conversation.content: [wearily] They called me at midnight saying you were here, and honestly, I wasn't even surprised—just exhausted thinking about doing this dance again.
[sheepishly] Look, I know what you're thinking, but this time it's different, I swear—I've been clean for six months and this was just wrong place, wrong time.

You realize I'm still paying off the lawyer from the last time you swore it was different, right? Twenty thousand dollars because I believed your story about the investment opportunity. [bitter laugh]
[defensively] That wasn't entirely my fault—Marcus was the one who pulled me into that scheme, and you know how persuasive he can be when he wants something.
[flatly] Always someone else.
No, listen, I'm trying to explain that I've learned from all that, okay? I've been working construction, staying with Mom, keeping my head down—this arrest is genuinely a misunderstanding.
The officer said you were caught with stolen merchandise in your car, so help me understand how that's a misunderstanding when the security footage shows you walking out with it.
[quickly] My buddy Jake asked me to hold onto some stuff while he moved apartments—I didn't know it was stolen, I thought he bought it from that going-out-of-business sale.
Jake. The same Jake who got you arrested three years ago for that check fraud thing where somehow I ended up being investigated too? [exhales] That Jake?
[quietly] Yeah, but he's changed too, we both have—people deserve second chances, or in my case, third or fourth chances, I guess.
Do you have any idea what it's like being known as the person who always bails you out? My coworkers literally have a betting pool on when you'll call next.
[wounded] That's not fair—I went two whole years without asking you for anything, and I only called tonight because Mom's too sick to handle this stress.
Mom's sick? [concerned] Since when is Mom sick? Why didn't anyone tell me she was sick?
She didn't want you to worry, said you had enough on your plate with the divorce and everything—it's her heart, they're doing tests after New Year's.
[softly] God, of course she didn't tell me, probably thought I'd blame you for the stress even though, [sighs], honestly I probably would have.
[earnestly] I'll pay you back.
You always say that, and then something happens—your car breaks down, you lose your job, someone else screws you over—and I end up eating the cost while you disappear again.
[firmly] This time I have a real job with benefits and everything, and I can set up automatic payments from my check—fifty dollars a week until it's all paid back.
[resigned] Fine, I'll post bail, but this is it—after this, you're on your own because I can't keep being your safety net. [pause]
[gratefully] I know I've burned through all my chances with you, but thank you—and Merry Christmas, I guess, even though this is the worst possible Christmas Eve reunion.
